title: Quiz 2: Critical Care - Sepsis, Shock & Burns
description: Advanced assessment on septicemia, types of shock, and burns management including the Parkland formula.

questions.question: Using the Rule of Nines for an adult, what is the estimated Total Body Surface Area (TBSA) for a patient with burns to the entire left arm and the entire anterior trunk?

richContent.content:
Body PartRule of 9s Value
Head9%
Each Arm9%
Anterior Trunk18%
Posterior Trunk18%
Each Leg18%

questions.explanation: Entire left arm (9%) + Entire anterior trunk (18%) = 27% TBSA.
questions.hint: Add the value for one arm and the front of the torso.

questions.question: Match the type of shock with its underlying pathophysiology:

pairs.right: Loss of blood or fluid volume

questions.explanation: Hypovolemic = fluid loss; Cardiogenic = heart failure; Neurogenic = nervous system loss of tone; Obstructive = blockage (e.g., PE, tamponade).

questions.question: A patient weighs 70 kg and has 50% TBSA burns. Using the Parkland Formula, calculate the TOTAL fluid volume required for the first 24 hours.
questions.explanation: 4 ml * 70 kg * 50 = 14,000 mL. Note: The formula uses the whole number for percentage (50), not the decimal (0.50).
questions.hint: Multiply 4 by the weight, then multiply that result by the percentage number.

questions.question: Which of the following are signs of the 'Progressive Stage' of shock? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: In the progressive stage, compensatory mechanisms fail. BP drops, organs suffer (oliguria, confusion), and acidosis accumulates. Normal BP is found in the compensatory stage.
questions.hint: This stage occurs when the body can no longer compensate, so look for signs of organ failure.

questions.question: Arrange the priorities of management for a patient in Anaphylactic Shock:
questions.explanation: Immediate safety (remove trigger), Airway is always priority (ABC), Epinephrine is the specific antidote, followed by adjunct meds.
questions.hint: Safety first, then ABCs, then the life-saving drug.

questions.question: In a Third Degree (Full Thickness) burn, the patient typically experiences extreme pain at the burn site.
questions.explanation: Third-degree burns involve destruction of the nerve endings, so the burn site itself is often painless (insensate), though surrounding areas may be painful.
questions.hint: Consider what happens to nerve endings when the entire skin thickness is destroyed.

questions.question: What is the name of the surgical procedure used to relieve pressure in compartment syndrome caused by circumferential burns?
questions.explanation: Escharotomy is the incision through the eschar (dead tissue) to relieve pressure and restore circulation.

questions.question: Which microorganism is the most common cause of Septicemia?
questions.explanation: While fungi and viruses can cause sepsis, bacterial infections (both Gram-positive and Gram-negative) are the leading cause.
questions.hint: Antibiotics are the primary treatment for sepsis because of this pathogen.

questions.question: According to the Parkland formula, ___BLANK___ of the calculated fluid volume should be administered in the first 8 hours post-injury.
questions.explanation: 50% of the total 24-hour volume is given in the first 8 hours; the remaining 50% is given over the next 16 hours.

questions.question: Which of the following are potential complications of Septicemia? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Sepsis causes systemic inflammation leading to clotting issues (DIC), lung failure (ARDS), and organ failure. It typically causes hypotension (shock), not hypertension.
questions.hint: Sepsis leads to low blood pressure and organ shut-down.
